pkg/api/v1alpha1/types.go.message:
no sure we need this variables since kind can be determined as
'ImageGenerator' property since it embeds TypeMeta

kind := &ImageGenerator{}.Kind

We will not need these constants when we will use apimachinery. It automatically generates gvk <-> types mappings when api objects are registered in a scheme. For now I will remote these two constants and create instead factory method to set Kind. But this is not safe since Kind will be overriden while unmarshalling.

I don't think that Kind information should come from this package. I do think, that is perfectly fine to have Kind come from document package instead of this one. Even though it seems like this should be a source of truth, actually it is not.

We do not want to mix documents "at-rest" and kubernetes resources. This way is how we interact with kubernetes, document package is to be used for documents at rest. If we used this for kubernetes, in the end RESTMapper will use CRD that comes from document set, to create Kind to API relationship, not this module, this will only be a helper.

> What I am saying, is that this IS NOT and IT SHOULD NOT be source
 > of truth. Actual mapping between at-rest documents and
 > api-resources, comes from CRD, not from schema or API object

It is, actually, not a valid statement. CRD MAY be called a source of truth for K8s api only but
1. Schema is mapping of reflect.Type to GVK (so mapping actually comes from it)
2. Go struct which defines API object is the ONLY source of truth even for K8s API considering CRDs are dynamically generated from go code. 

That being said static selectors can be implemented as a workaround to avoid additional dependency for this CR

The Kind here is set manually because selector byGvk requires Kind argument to get necesessary document from the bundle. I can  use another selector (by name or by label) if you insist. Anyway this field will be overriden (with the same value) during deserialization. 

Regarding source of truth. Well, if we use (or rather when we use) apimachinery/controller-runtime for dealing with our api the name of api struct is going to be exactly the source of truth https://github.com/kubernetes/apimachinery/blob/master/pkg/runtime/scheme.go#L158-L159

Dmitry had the same question and we agreed that it is temprorary solution until we move to apimachinery. In fact, if you take a look at patchset 27 of the this patch you'll see I was going to use apimachinery, but then decided to make it as simple as possible to make review process faster.

What I am saying, is that this IS NOT and IT SHOULD NOT be source of truth. Actual mapping between at-rest documents and api-resources, comes from CRD, not from schema or API object, so using schema or API objects at rest to filter documents doesn't make sense, unless we have document.Bundle Method that would filter that uses schema itself, Dmitry example here: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735046/2/pkg/document/bundle.go

So my suggestion is either rebase on top of that, or add "hardcoded" selector function to get appropriate selector. Both ways would work, however I strongly believe that doing this temporary solution can cause confusion which can easily be avoided, by using document module to supply these constants, instead of trying to understand them from Api module.

I think it's possible to run libvirt without the privileged flag. We can do that by adding only the devices that it needs, following the principle of least privilege.
There is a good writeup about that [1], although it's for lxd:

https://dshcherb.github.io/2017/12/04/qemu-kvm-virtual-machines-in-unprivileged-lxd.html

Hi, please note the important point below:

'nova_libvirt' container is "inherently a highly privileged container because Nova requires it to be able to perform many highly privileged actions."

In other words, we're *NOT* using containers for security isolation—but only for ease of deployment.

Securing VMs from each other is taken care by sVirt.

Hope that makes things clear.

Hi, I agree containers in TripleO were initially used for ease of delivery and not security (a quick look at the code is sufficient to get to this conclusion), but there is an ongoing effort to change that. This is because any security audit will point at the current usage of containers and expect it to be "fixed". I'll send you an email with some details which I can't discuss on the wide forum here. This long term effort was discussed at the PTG:

https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/tripleo-ptg-victoria-distro-transition

In this instance, container isolation wouldn't be used for securing the VMs, but for isolating the TripleO services from each other.

Having said that, nova_libvirt, which probably needs the most privileges, is not necessarily the one container we are focusing on right now. We already moved some containers off of running privileged, but there are still more services, which shouldn't have any privileges at all, using the privileged option (originally created only for running docker inside docker).

The point four here can be confusing as it gives the impression that this patch is using 'container_ro_file_t'—now it's not anymore, given the "Notes" below.

How about this:

4- In this patch, we use the SELinux 'container_share_t'.  In a future patch we will update it to 'container_ro_file_t'. This is purely a cosmetic change to better reflect the actual behavior of the SELinux label; this does not alter functionality.  (Also, refer to point 2 in the "Notes" section below.)

deployment/nova/nova-libvirt-container-p.message:

So we should make sure to change 'container_share_t' to 'container_ro_file_t' here.

I find the above paragraph somewhat confusing.
Does systemd-coredump run in host namespace or pod namespace?  It sounds like it runs in host namespace.  It sounds like to be successful, the pid handed to it has to not exist as a running process.  Pids from inside pods tend to be lower numbers and thus more likely to collide with pids on the host, appearing to exist from the host perspective and thus fail to dump.

systemd-coredump runs as root:root on the host.

%p is the PID in the pod's namespace. %P is PID in the host's namespace.  In this paragraph I'm answering the bug report's observation of intermittent core dumps.  I'm not saying that the PID has to not exist.  I'm saying that, when using %p (wrong, but...), it if happens to not exist in host's namespace then systemd-coredump won't segfault.  The core file appears ok.

%P should be used.

NOTE: In JavaScript, When an argument is not specified by a caller, it will defaults to "undefined". This change does not break horizon plugins. I think the only side effect is to lose existing translations for languages which do not hit this issue.

It looks like this issue has been somewhat mitigated in newer Django version by better handling missing translations. This makes the main error case go away — they fall back to the English translation, which happens to be the same. However, it will still use the wrong plural form in languages that, unlike English, have more than one plural, and it may leave the titles untranslated in other languages.

I wonder if we should actually *set* the stores in failed_import if we're pre-empting that task. If it's still running and wakes up to find the lock removed, it will not be able to update this list anyway, which is good, because it would be racing with this task which is about to grab the lock.

So, we could compare image['stores'] to task['input']['stores'] and only put failed ones in the failed list, but that could also be error-prone. I think the important thing is that they come out of the in-progress list so that it doesn't look like they're still being imported.

Comments here from other people which probably have strong opinions.

The airshipctl can be considered as a smart client into the handling of manifests, which can then give the duty to other tools.

For the workflow case, airshipctl can generate the workflow documents, the deployer then deploys the resulting CRDs document into its environment.

That will open the door to many things, including forks of some part of the code.

I believe, in this case, that it's better to have a plugin system, in order to increase adoption.

openssh-config/files/sshd_config.message: What's the purpose of this option? What's the impact to use "sanbox" vs "yes"?

"sandbox" is the required setting for "Enable Use of Privilege Separation" rule to pass the security scan. This is from the scan recommendation:
---To enable privilege separation in SSH, add or correct the following line in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file:

UsePrivilegeSeparation sandbox
---

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
I understand and support the purpose of this change but also wanted to bring up one potential problem with it which I think we need to test carefully

We'll end up with the backups of the mons having each a different epoch, because every time a mon is stopped/started the other two will bump up the cluster epoch as a consequence of the cluster reconfiguration

The mon last stopped will be the one having in its backup the highest epoch

On restore, the mons have to be started all three at the same time though which should work but was curious if we tested this?
ack, election_epoch was the same on the three nodes

Yes, this was tested.
We havent checked the epoch, but the content of ceph was tested with a python script to ensure that the content was there.

Basically, we used the overcloud pingtest to create a stack.
To make things more complicated, we created a different stack on every node backup of the control-plane.
- We created an stack
- Backup the /var/lib/ceph on controller-0
- We created different stack
- Backup the /var/lib/ceph on controller-1
- Created different stack 
- Backup the /var/lib/ceph on controller-2

After the restoration we check the content of ceph.
it might still be not sufficient though, investigating further, sorry

problem in this scenario is that the cluster will never lose quorum, hence when the last of the mons is getting "snapshotted" (say, node3) the other two (of which a backup was already taken) might be acking new epoc change requests which osds *will remember*

on restore though, the most updated copy of the osds map will be that of node3, the other two mons will eventually sync up but none of the three will have the latest epoch which was instead acked to osds by node1/node2 while they were still online

the only safe way to take a "working" backup of the mons is to do so when the cluster *is not quorate* because that is the only scenario in which it will refuse to incorporate changes which might make the backup useless

given these are straight role imports we can probably use the `roles` directive within the playbook to better organize the code.

Something like so 

  - name: upgrade ceph mdss cluster, deactivate all rank > 0
    hosts: "{{ groups[mon_group_name|default('mons')][0] }}"
    become: true
    roles:
      - role: ceph-defaults
        when:
          - groups.get(mds_group_name, []) | length > 0
      - role: ceph-facts
        when:
          - groups.get(mds_group_name, []) | length > 0
    post_tasks:
      - name: deactivate all mds rank > 0 if any
        when: groups.get(mds_group_name, []) | length > 1
        block:
          ...


Which provides some nice organization and flow control, while also avoiding the nested blocks.

Right but I think that by default if you do this and one of the nodes in the inventory is not available, i think this will fail the playbook here. Even if not targeted by the rest of the playbook.  Just something to look into as end users typically end up with a server or two dead at some point

This patch does not look into that, as nothing on the ceph cluster is backed it up.

The idea of this, it's to restore the control-plane in the same status as it was when the backup process happened. Ceph is an exception of this, as the ceph cluster needs to keep the status as it is in the moment of the restoration process.

This call needs to be replaced with the new _authorize method too
The signature of _authorize should match the signature of _ENFORCER.authorize so that it may be used as a complete wrapper for all calls

The idea behind wrapping calls to _ENFORCER.authorize is to handle FileNotFoundError for all callers who call _ENFORCER.authorize. The original _ENFORCER.authorize method supports the following arguments:

https://github.com/openstack/oslo.policy/blob/6296fce9f8e3205506f87dd31d0b18f4b7842000/oslo_policy/policy.py#L1055-L1056

So we need to allow callers to pass the same arguments when they call the wrapper method _authorize.

What you can do here actually is have the signature be:

 def _authorize(*args, **kwargs)

so that you will support everything support by _ENFORCER.authorize.
Catches
You don't need this, you can remove it.

So now that you have support for all *args and **kwargs, here you can just pass them through to the policy authorize method:

releasenotes/notes/fix-allocation-range-.message:
The release notes tooling doesn't separate notes by commits/changes - it aggregates all upgrade notes into an "Upgrade Notes" section. See for example: https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/tripleo-heat-templates/train.html#relnotes-11-1-0-stable-train-upgrade-notes


So you'll have to explain the context in every note item here..

Do we need an upgrade section here?

If someone deployed with the previous defaults, and then updates with this new default the update will fail. The CIDR of the existing neutron subnet cannot be updated.

Hmm, I guess I need to do some re-testing.  I thought I saw that changes to the StorageNFS allocation-ranges and CIDR didn't take effect on re-deploys, even if I supplied '[CREATE,UPDATE]'.  Is there something special about *upgrades* in this regard, or will just doing a brownfield re-deploy with the candidate change be sufficient to test?

A brownfield re-deploy should trigger the issue.
I expect the heat resource for the network to fail on update if the CIDR changed? Or heat may try to delete the network and recreate it, since a non-updatable property changed?

Thanks, Harald!  I have done several brownfield redeploys in an effort to improve my own understanding of the issue.
It seems that if I modify only the allocation pool range for the StorageNFS network there is no upgrade issue per se except that the new allocation pool definition has no effect since the relevant IPs have already been assigned to the Controller nodes (these are the nodes that have interfaces on StorageNFS) and to the Ganesha VIP and these assignments have been preserved in ansible variables and inventory files in /var/lib/mistral/overcloud.
But if I change the CIDR then as you indicate the brownfield overcloud_deploy fails with the error:
UPDATE_FAILED  NotSupported: resources.StorageNFSSubnet: Update to properties cidr of StorageNFSSubnet (OS::Neutron::Subnet) is not supported.
Since we want to change the CIDR I will add an 'Upgrade:' release note as you suggest.

sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclien.message: In what case would the 'ca_file' parameter be provided but not the actual value? Is there a bug somewhere that needs to be fixed? Should we log that? Should we raise and exception in that case?

> OK - then isn't the bug in the shell code? If --ca-file isn't
 > provided, then there should be no ca_file kwarg.

I'd rather fix it here as this is an obvious bug in the condition.
Fixing it here is good, but I also want at least an error log and the calling code fixed.
OK - then isn't the bug in the shell code? If --ca-file isn't provided, then there should be no ca_file kwarg.

Would like Jerry to comment. He originally added the code in shell.py that sets the ca_cert to this if the --ca-file parameter is not provided:
default=utils.env('OS_CACERT')

That seems to be the source of this bug. It looks like the way this is supposed to work is that if the above change was not made, the VerifiedHTTPSConnection clas would see that ca_file was None and would call self.get_system_ca_file. Why was that not good enough? Or... why wouldn't we modify that function instead?

This change was originally done because the CA certificate was not used with an HTTPS system through remote CLI. I am not sure if the self.get_system_ca_file did anything back when i made the change. At the end of the day, it was to fix a situation where the CA certificate was not being used when talking to an HTTPS enabled system (this only happened in remote CLI since the controller did not run HTTPS back then and DC was not a thing).

> In what case would the 'ca_file' parameter be provided but not the
 > actual value? Is there a bug somewhere that needs to be fixed?
 > Should we log that? Should we raise and exception in that case?

If the command is provided with a --ca-file, it will take it and works as expected. The issue I'm fixing here is when command is not provide ca-file. In this case the kwargs['ca_file'] (and thus ca_cert) is an empty string ('') instead of None, literally making an empty string as the default ca-file which overrides the real default ca files later in the call stack.

> Fixing it here is good, but I also want at least an error log and
 > the calling code fixed.

Do you mean fix the empty string shell.py? I'm not sure returning empty string is a bug or design intention, the function to get ca-file from environment ( env(*vars, **kwargs) ) is generic code in common/utils.py, changing that would impact many args passed to sysinv command.

nova/api/openstack/compute/services.py.message:
So this can happen when one host failed so the service does not run, instances successfully evacuated from the host and now the admin wants to delete the failed service. The source host allocation is not deleted during the evacuation as it left for the source host to delete it after it is recovered. However in the above case the source host never recovered so we have still allocation against it therefore the service deletion fails. 

I see two possible way forward:
1) Document this case heavily and ask the admin to clean up the allocation manually. 

2) Add a check for the sevice deletion code to see if there are finished evacuations where the source host is the host that is being deleted. And if so check if there are any allocation left due to the finished evacuation and deleted them before deleting the RP tree.

releasenotes/notes/qemu-accept-vmxnet3-n.message: More details here about what use case this actually enables would be great.

Presumably this means saving the VM as a disk image, then booting it on OpenStack? Does ESXi support exporting disk images in formats that OpenStack understands? I'm asking because - if we add support for the VIF model, but are missing support for the image format, we're not actually enabling the full use case.

You need to retrieve the correct vmdk from the datastore. The one finishing with -flat.vmdk is actually a raw disk image that can be converted to any format. For instance here I download a vcenter disk image from an ESXi, and convert it to the qcow2 format:

curl -v -k --user 'root:!234AaAa56' -o vCenterServerAppliance.raw 'https://192.168.123.5/folder/vCenter-Server-Appliance/vCenter-Server-Appliance-flat.vmdk?dcPath=ha%252ddatacenter&dsName=local'
virt-sparsify --tmp tmp --compress --convert qcow2 vCenterServerAppliance.raw vCenterServerAppliance.qcow2

> Presumably this means saving the VM as a disk image, then booting
 > it on OpenStack? Does ESXi support exporting disk images in formats
 > that OpenStack understands? I'm asking because - if we add support
 > for the VIF model, but are missing support for the image format,
 > we're not actually enabling the full use case.

Answering my own question - looks like qemu-img can convert from vdi or vmdk to qcow2. OTOH, looks like ESXi only exports to OVA/OVF? So what's the proposed workflow here?

I guess the actual migration procedure is out of scope for a release note, but I wanted to be sure that just enabling the VIF model is enough to support it. I assume there'll be a blog post or doc somewhere explaining how to export from EXSi and import to OpenStack... ;)
